name: Tesla
mission: Accelerate the world�s transition to sustainable energy.
previewHook: Tesla is accelerating the world�s transition to sustainable energy.
description: Tesla develops all-electric vehicles that aim to be superior to fossil-fuel alternatives.  Tesla also produces energy generation and storage products to power both urban and remote communities with reliable, afordable energy.
notes: In 2006, prior to the launch of the Tesla Roadster, there was no viable all-electric vehicle option on the market. Now, 12 years later, there are over 3M electric vehicles on the road globally, with more being produced every day. The auto industry is moving towards electrification, and governments around the world have recognized the harmful impact of internal combustion engine (ICE) vehicle emissions and have started to take concrete steps towards making the future more environmentally friendly and sustainable. Since then, Tesla has launched countless products that have succeeded in the early adopter market, with more recent additions like the Cybertruck and Solar Roof aimed at the mainstream. Over 550K Tesla vehicles have been sold, and they have driven over 10B miles to date, resulting in a combined savings of over 4M metric tons of CO2.
founders: Martin Eberhard, Marc Tarpenning, Elon Musk, J. B. Straubel, Ian Wright
impact: sourcing sustainable materials, uses renewable energy, good working environment, avoids conflict minerals, product avoids fossil fuel use, designed for longevity, providing higher quality product to carbon intensive alternative
transparency: has webpage about impact, has yearly impact report, specific numbers available, traces supply chain, open sources patents

name: Lime
mission: Through the equitable distribution of shared scooters, bikes and transit vehicles, we aim to reduce dependence on personal automobiles for short distance transportation and leave future generations with a cleaner, healthier planet.
previewHook: Last mile transport that runs on 100% renewable energy
description: Electric scooters as a solution for last mile transit.
notes: Lime charges their entire fleet with 100% renewable energy, and they neutralize the emissions of our operations vehicle fleet by supporting carbon offset projects. However, it's unclear if scooters are the right solution.�In the last two years no scooter company has turned a profit. In October 2019, Lime announced it is predicting to lose about $300 million in 2019. Lime operates scooters, bikes, and vans.
impact: offset production, uses renewable energy, product avoids fossil fuel use
transparency: has webpage about impact

name: Bird
mission: We are riding toward a more livable world. As cities across the globe continue to grow, so too does our need for greater mobility. We�re facing more pollution, congestion, and gridlock than ever before. The near-term solution is in partnering with cities to rebalance our existing streets and improve the way we all get around, not in adding more cars to our roads or redesigning the entire transit landscape.
previewHook: Bird rides are carbon neutral. E-scooters are charged using a regular wall outlet.
description: The other scooter company.
notes: Partners with 3Degrees for carbon offsets. Won a sustainable development goal award. https://www.bird.co/blog/renewable-energy-credits-and-carbon-offsets/. It has raised a lot of money but it's unclear how big of a positive impact it's had so far considering the short lifecycle of the scooters. Manufacturers are Xiaomi and Segway.
impact: offsets production, product avoids fossil fuel use

name: Bikeshare
description: The L.A. Bikeshare system is not a specific company but is here to highlight the abundance of local options for last mile transit.
notes: Bike sharing has shown big environmental benefits. In Shanghai alone, bike sharing saved 8,358 tons of gasoline and reduced CO2 emissions by 25,240 tons in 2016, according to a study published this June in the journal Applied Energy.
impact: product avoids fossil fuel use, stimulates local economy, no additional production
transparency: overall numbers available by program, usually it's quite clear - calculate the miles you would have driven instead for emissions impact

name: Raven And Lily
mission: Raven + Lily is an ethical fashion and lifestyle brand dedicated to empowering women through jobs by design.
description: A certified B Corp, Raven + Lily has made fair labor practices integral to the brand identity.
notes: Designed in Austin, Texas, Raven + Lily�s pieces are made by female artisans at fair-trade wages in countries like Ethiopia, Peru, India, and Kenya from sustainable materials like deadstock fabrics and fair-trade organic cotton.
impact: carbon neutral, eco friendly, fair trade, handmade, woman made, microloan program
transparency: has webpage about impact, b corp certified

name: Aiayu
mission: Combine beauty, comfort and sustainable living.
description: Danish brand Aiayu sells knits and textiles for the home.
notes: To take responsibility throughout the value chain and ensure full transparency of all the key processes, Aiayu works with only one manufacturer that covers the entire supply chain from sorting of fiber dyeing, spinning and finishing production. The brand runs a zero-waste program that recycles production leftovers into products like tote bags and rugs, publicly discloses its certifications, and has been a member of the Global Compact since 2008. All products are made from materials like alpaca wool, organic cotton, and yak fibers. Products are packaged in biodegradable materials, and Aiayu will repair anything for you free of charge (as long as repairs are possible).
founders: Maria Heilmann, Marie Worsaae, Maria Glaesel
impact: zero waste program for textiles, repair program, bio-degradable packaging, single manufacturer, all natural materials,
transparency: has webpage about impact, GOTS certified, SA8000 certified, WRAP certified, member of Global Compact
quote: A sustainable wardrobe and home starts with quality items made from materials that are natural and durable. Designs that are timeless finished in materials that will last, encouraging consumers to buy fewer, better things. Consciously investing for the future is also a way to put it.

name: Kowtow
mission: We make a conscious decision to only use renewable and sustainable fibres and ethical manufacturing to deliver collections that are utilitarian, minimal and carry an understated sense of femininity.
description: New Zealand brand Kowtow offers simple and stylish clothes.
notes: All products are made from fair-trade-certified organic cotton (dyed within Global Organic Textile Standards). Its factory in India pays its workers a living wage, in addition to providing benefits like paid holiday leave, sick pay, medical insurance, and overtime pay, as well as free schooling for their children and free transportation to and from work.
impact: sourcing sustainable materials, sourcing from responsibly managed forests, using waste as material, removing plastic from the ocean, recyclable packaging, repair program, take back program
transparency: has webpage about impact, disclose standard for sourcing all materials, fair trade certified, manufactured in SA8000 certified organisations

name: People Tree
mission: To support producer partners' efforts towards economic independence and control over their environment and to challenge the power structures that undermine their rights to a livelihood.
description: London-based label has been a pioneer for sustainable fashion since 1991.
notes: In 2013, People Tree became the first brand to receive the WFTO Fair Trade product mark. Almost all of their line is made with organic cotton, and 89 percent of their suppliers are currently undertaking environmental initiatives.
impact: sourcing sustainable materials, some garments made by small producer groups in Bangladesh and Nepal
transparency: has webpage about impact, disclose standard for sourcing all materials, 93% GOTS certified cotton

name: Nudie Jeans
mission: Our vision is to become the most sustainable denim company.
description: Nudie's vision is to become the most sustainable denim company.
notes: Of the companies on this list, their sustainability report is one of the most thorough! In it they disclose every number a consumer could possibly ask for, the next best thing would be a real-time impact counter. Their 100 percent organic cotton jeans last for a long time, and Nudie will repair them for you anytime free of charge. They willrecycle your old jeans into new products in exchange for a 20 percent discount off your next purchase. This year it looks like they are undertaking an offsetting program for every pair of jeans. In addition, the brand has won multiple sustainable fashion awards and maintains a public code of conduct.
founders: Maria Erixon, Joakim Levin, Palle Stenberg
impact: sourcing sustainable materials, pay living wages, carbon offset exports through the UPS Carbon Neutral program, part of Swedish Textile Initiative for Climate Action, repair program, 100% organic cotton,
transparency: has webpage about impact, yearly impact report, discloses suppliers, traces production, code of conduct audits by Fair Wear Foundation audit teams
quote: People have everything repaired, from their cell phone to their car. Just not their jeans. How come?

name: Pact
previewHook: Building the world's first guilt-free fashion brand.
description: Pact creates sustainable basics.
notes: It uses fair trade certified factories and certified organic cotton. There aren't many specific numbers available on the site, but it's a good place to start for sustainable clothing at a more affordable price (especially because you can't thrift underwear)
impact: 100% organic cotton, good working environment
transparency: has webpage about impact, fair trade factories

name: Veja
description: A Parisian brand that makes stylish kicks in Brazil from sustainable materials.
notes: Veja sources their materials like no other shoe brand. 90% of the 72,500 kWh consumed by VEJA in 2018 came from renewable sources (two offices, three shops in Paris). Our Brazilian office uses the national grid made out of 65% hydro powered electricity. Veja maintains a code of conduct and works with employees from Atelier Sans Fronti�res, an organization that promotes the professional integration of people exclduded from the labour market. A VEJA costs 5 to 7 times as much to produce as a competing pair of sneakers. They've cut ads to sell their shoes for the same price as competing brands. Instead, they've got folks like Meghan Markle sporting their shoes for some free public exposure.
impact: set price of organic cotton, fair trade and organic raw materials, good working conditions, upcycling waste
transparency: has webpage about impact, has specific numbers available, maps production, organic certification, tests for chemicals, certified B Corp

name: Kings of Indigo
previewHook: Kings of Indigo is primarily known for their denim.
description: Kings of Indigo is primarily known for their denim but produces many styles for men and women.
notes: Kings of Indigo is extremely transparent about its supply chain, publishing a production map and regularly visiting its factories. The brand uses 90 percent organic cotton in its denim, plus a fabric that combines organic cotton, recycled cotton, and hemp. It also uses dyeing and distressing techniques that reduce water consumption throughout the process. Most recently KOI ran "Blue Friday," a campaign to donate 100,000 liters of clean water for every jean purchased dring Black Friday.
impact: sourcing sustainable materials, purchase for a cause
transparency: has webpage about impact, lists production locations, signed transparency pledge, signed Agreement on Sustainable Garments and Textiles, traces supply chain
quote: We have a unique concept - sustainability, mixed with quality and fashion - which I think is a good combination and not a mixture many companies have been able to achieve.

name: Patagonia
mission: We�re in business to save our home planet.
description: Patagonia is a leader in environmental and social responsibility on many fronts.
notes: Their climate goal is to eliminate or mitigate all of our carbon emissions by 2025. Their specific plan involves measuring their impact, reducing it, converting to renewables, and capturing carbon. In addition, they provide many grants through their internal investment arm, Tin Shed Ventures. A comprehensive audit revealed their emissions per scope from 2017 amounted to 141,003 metric tonnes of CO2e, with 86 percent of those emissions coming from the creation of materials. In addition to being fair-trade certified for all its sewing production Patagonia publicly discloses all of its first-tier suppliers, and is actively working to map out the rest down to the farm level for raw materials. Patagonia is probably the most climate aligned apparel brand on the market. Patagonia also supports an internal drive less program and is in the process of switching entirely to renewables.
impact: sourcing sustainable materials, specific numbers available, good working environment, funds conservation efforts, providing grants, 1% for the planet, repair program, supporting a Regenerative Organic Certification
transparency: has webpage about impact, has specific numbers available, publishes yearly impact report, B Corp certified, climate specific action plan, Chemical and Environmental Impacts Program

name: Reformation
mission: Make effortless silhouettes that celebrate the feminine figure.
description: LA-based, eco-conscious label known for high-slit dresses.
notes: The brand started out selling re-worked vintage pieces in 2009; now eight years old, Reformation still sells vintage in-store, but has branched out with an online empire focusing on party dresses and casual everyday pieces. While Reformation is not cheap, but almost everything is made in the US at the brand�s own factory with sustainable fabrics and production methods. The entire environmental footprint of each garment is shown on the site and on its tag. Using it's internal Ref Scale, Reformation puts numbers to the CO2 emitted, gallons of water used, and pounds of waste produced for a specific item.
impact: sourcing sustainable materials, good working environment, avoiding waste, avoiding ghg emissions, conserving water, disclose manufacturing locations
transparency: has webpage about impact, has specific numbers available, publishes yearly impact report, has per unit impact numbers
quote: We start off by asking, what are the biggest issues facing the environment? [...] I would say that the No. 1 biggest issue right now is climate change. Climate change is directly affected by how many greenhouse gas emissions are in the atmosphere, so we�re very, very focused on projects that reduce greenhouse gas emissions specifically.

name: Buffalo Exchange
description: Brick and mortar thrift shop franchise with stores across America and a seller friendly buy back program.
impact: sourcing locally, creating circular economy, preserving land, preserving water

name: ThredUP
previewHook: Buying one used item reduces its carbon footprint by 82%.
description: thredUP is a fashion resale marketplace that enables individuals to buy and sell clothing for women and children.
notes: According to ThredUp's 2019 Resale Report, we are buying twice as much clothing and wearing it half as long. The overabundance of orphaned clothing makes secondhand the perfect solution for fashion addicts who feel guilty about their waste and wallet. It prevents production of toxic or exploitative new clothing, and it keeps textiles out of the landfill or from being shipped overseas. Secondhand stores are almost all charitable, locally, or family-owned, so you direct your dollars away from multinational corporations and to small business. And best of all, it�s a way to get fresh threads (sometimes with the tags still on!) for fast-fashion prices. Resale plays a key role in a circular fashion future, and choosing used combats the harmful effects of textile waste.
founders: Chris Homer, James Reinhart, Oliver Lubin
impact: creating circular economy, avoiding ghg emissions, preserving water, conserving electricity, avoid unecessary manufacturing
transparency: has webpage about impact, has yearly impact report, specific numbers available, third party verified

name: Eclipse Foods
mission: We are here to create a more sustainable, responsible and humane food system�with your help
previewHook: Still quite early, Eclipse Foods is trying to be the Impossible Foods of dairy.
description: Eclipse started with ice cream and launched in November 2019.
notes: Within the past few years, vegan ice cream has become easy to find in the Bay Area. But creameries rely on coconut milk or nut milks for the base, resulting in ice creams that taste like, well, coconut or nuts. Eclipse�s ice cream base, however, is made out of common, inexpensive ingredients like potato, corn, cassava and canola oil. The founders said they�re proud that it�s also free of common allergens like soy, nuts and gluten as well as gums, stabilizers and genetically modified ingredients.
impact: conserving land, conserving water, preventing deforestation, providing higher quality product to carbon intensive alternative
transparency: has webpage about impact

name: Ripple Foods
mission: Dairy Free. As it Should Be.
previewHook: Cleaner plant-based dairy and almond alternatives.
description: Ripple creates plant-based dairy alternatives that are even lower in environmental impact than almond based dairy alternatives.
notes: Their products are powered by Ripptein, their proprietary pea-based protein. Unlike almonds, which require irrigation; or cattle, which contribute to deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions; peas have a small environmental footprint. With water scarcity taken into account, growing almonds requires 100 times as much water per ton of crop as dry peas. Dairy milk requires 25 times more water per liter of milk than Ripple. Yellow peas grow in areas that receive lots of rain, so they need little or no irrigation. Ripple�s bottles are also made from 100% post-consumer recycled plastic; and that plastic can be recycled by 94% of US households. Their website site has a real time counter that documents its "Ripple Effect." Their carbon impact is impressive (60M lbs saved), but their water impact even more so (186B gallons!). Most recently, Ripple was awarded a grant by the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation to develop sustainable, high protein food options for people in the developing world.
impact: conserving carbon, conserving water, providing higher quality product to carbon intensive alternative, avoiding virgin plastic
transparency: has webpage about impact, public benefit corporation, specific numbers are available, real time impact counter, yearly impact report
quote: I make milk! And I used to make soap. But it�s more than that. [...] I want to redefine success in business from simple financial returns to a more shared and durable prosperity. Business is the largest and most powerful force for change on the planet, so business has the onus to improve the state of the world and the people living in it. Doing so requires redesigning business itself. That�s what I really do for a living!

name: Beyond Meat
mission: Create The Future of Protein. Delicious plant-based burgers, beef, sausage, crumbles, and more.
description: Producer of plant-based meat substitutes.
notes: By shifting from animal to plant-based meat, Beyond Meat addresses four growing global issues: human health, climate change, constraints on natural resources, and animal welfare. Compared to Impossible Foods, Beyond sells its plant-based burger, sausage and other products mostly at retail, though a growing number of chains, such as Carl�s Jr. and TGI Fridays, now carry them. Compared to a quarter pound beef burger, Beyond Burger requires: 99% less water, 93% less land, 90% fewer greenhouse gas emissions, nearly 50% less energy.
impact: conserving land, conserving water, preventing deforestation, providing higher quality product to carbon intensive alternative, conserving energy
transparency: has webpage about impact, peer reviewed life cycle assessment

name: Impossible Foods
mission: Replace the need for animals as a food-production technology � globally, by 2035.
description: Known for the Impossible Burger, this company develops plant-based substitutes for meat products.
notes: The company's aim aim is to give people the taste and nutritional benefits of meat without supposed negative health and certain environmental impacts associated with livestock products. The company researches animal products at the molecular level, then selects specific proteins and nutrients from plants to recreate the experience and nutrition of specific meat products
impact: conserving land, conserving water, preventing deforestation, providing higher quality product to carbon intensive alternative
transparency: has webpage about impact, has yearly impact report, specific numbers available, third party verified
quote: The only consumer we care about is the hardcore meat lover.

name: Mosa Meats
mission: Our mission is to revolutionise the way meat is made
description: Mosa Meats produces cultured meat.
notes: If everyone were to adopt a plant-based diet, it would be better as these products are even more sustainable than cultured meat. However, Mosa Meats is concerned that many people will not want to become vegetarian or vegan, especially given plant-based substitutes will never be exactly the same in taste and texture as meat. Therefore, Mosa Meats is looking explorgin a new avenue of replacing livestock by producing cultured meat. Cultured meat (or "clean meat") is the same as conventional meat but, instead of slaughtering a whole animal, Mosa Meats produces the meat by growing animal cells.
impact: conserving land, conserving water, preventing deforestation

name: OLIO
mission: Create a world in which nothing of value goes to waste, and every single person has enough to eat � without destroying our planet in the process.
description: OLIO connects neighbours with each other and with local businesses so surplus food can be shared, not thrown away.
notes: OLIO is a bit small and their current impact is unclear, but the potential for impact is masive. According to the Food an Agriculture Organization of the UN (FAO) over 1/3 of food produced goes to waste, half of which happens in the home. On OLIO's site (unclear when last updated), 2,753,127 portions of food have been shared.
impact: creating circular economy, sourcing locally, preventing deforestation, conserving water, conserving land
transparency: has webpage about impact

name: Farmer's market
description: Plenty of local options throughout the states for farmer's markets. Find the one nearest to you on Google Maps.
notes: Not much to say here other than it's a great choice to go to the farmer's market and support local producers when you can.
impact: sourcing sustainably, sourcing locally
transparency: just ask the farmers!

name: Amazon
description: E-commerce, cloud computing, digital streaming, and artificial intelligence
notes: Amazon recently purchased 100,000 all-electric vehicles to join its delivery fleet.
impact: run multiple large scale initiatives, reducing impact of supply chain, replacing fleet with all electric vehicles
transparency: has webpage about impact, has specific numbers available

name: Walmart
previewHook: Undertaking Project Gigaton to avoid 1 billion metric tons of GHG emissions by 2035.
description: Retail corporation that operates a chain of hypermarkets, discount department stores, and grocery stores.
impact: using renewable energy, avoiding plastic packaging, incentivizing supply chain to cut carbon
transparency: has webpage about impact, has specific numbers available, publishes yearly impact report,

name: Fairphone
mission: Bring a fair smartphone to the market, one designed and produced with minimal harm to people and planet
previewHook: Started as a campaign for fairer electronics, and now produces ethical smartphones.
description: Fairphone is a certified B-corp and has created the world�s first ethical smartphone.
notes: Fairphone launched the movement for fairer electronics. The company makes a positive impact across the value chain in mining, design, manufacturing and life cycle, while expanding the market for products that put ethical values first. The company believes in sourcing conflict-free materials that support local economies, not armed militias. Fairphone works closely with manufacturers that want to invest in employee wellbeing and ethical worker practices. The company is also addressing the full lifespan of mobile phones, including use, reuse and safe recycling programs that make it easy to recycle your Fairphone, so the parts can be re-purposed and not end up in landfills and the ocean.
founders: Bas van Abel, Tessa Wernink, Miquel Ballester
impact: ewaste recycling program, sourcing sustainable materials, sourcing conflict free materials, good working conditions, design for longevity
transparency: has webpage about impact, specific numbers available, traces supply chain, bcorp certified, fair trade certified, public benefit corporation
quote: We create a platform for other companies to think about sustainability, to have a more mature debate about the dilemmas you run into as a company in terms of sustainability because we run into those issues ourselves. That puts us in a position, where we can drive the agenda in terms of what needs to happen on the ground.

name: Nimble
description: Nimble is a consumer tech brand committed to creating high-quality, eco-friendly tech products.
notes: According to their site, 80% of a product�s environmental impact is decided at the design stage. They select materials for the sake of durability, performance, and sustainability. They are always aiming to use more materials like recycled plastic, organic hemp, recycled aluminum, plant-based bioplastic, and more. All of their packaging is plastic free.
founders: Ross Howe, Kevin Malinowski, Jon Bradley
impact: ewaste recycling program, sourcing sustainable materials, good working conditions, design for longevity, 1% for the planet member
transparency: has webpage about impact, b corp certified, public benefit corporation

name: Rent the Runway
description: Designer dress and accessory rentals.
impact: circular economy, plastic-free packaging, no fast fashion
transparency: has webpage about impact
